page.title: 10Local History of Alford
page.content: The Alford area contains several archaeological sites - an earth house, stone circles and standing stones. These are more abundant in the Don valley than elsewhere. This suggests that early settlers favoured the stoneless soils of the river haugh- lands. Several Gaelic names survive in the names of the farms eg. Ard- gathen (breezy height) and Balquharn (town of the cairns), others are of mixed Lowland Scots and English origin eg. Birkhill, Smiddyhill, Waterside, Scotsmill. The oldest name in the area is probably the River Don which may be Pictish or even earlier. Alford itself comes from the Gaelic "a" a ford. Montgarrie is Gaelic monadh garbh (rough moor). The most famous event in Alford's history was Mont- rose's victory over the Covenanters near the Bridge of Alford in 1645.
